results.title: What about me?: young people and local government
results.creator_credit: TV Ed Productions, Ivan Gaal and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Katie, a Year 12 student wants to find out more about what her Local City Council can do for her. This program follows her inquiries and shows what she discovers.

results.title: What about juvenile delinquency?
results.creator_credit: Centron Production and Young America Films
results.brief_description: A gang of high school delinquents discover that the man they assaulted was the father of Jamie, one of their gang members. When Jamie learns the truth about the incident, he joins forces with the ‘good’ students to combat juvenile delinquency. A social guidance film intended to trigger classroom discussion in American school students.

results.title: What about I.F.C?
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Don Murray and Arch Nicholson
results.brief_description: Comparison with another firm in the same business and of approximately the same size can be of immense value to management in evaluating their own firm’s performance. The film is directed at management of firms from the smallest grocer to the largest corporation and is designed to show the advantages of I.F.C. The film is directed at small firms and large corporations.

results.title: What's your authority?
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Gregory Heimer
results.brief_description: Presents two episodes involving children confronting the problems of authority. Examines the kinds of authority found in our society and the individual’s relation to authority. Produced by Greg Heimer in collaboration with Lawrence Kohlberg, Phd. Harvard.

results.title: What's wrong with this picture?
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Sonia Whiteman
results.brief_description: Shot in 16mm and VHS, this film is reminiscent of the silent era. The main character, a young man, lives in a world filled with paradoxes; he drives through a shopping mall, walks backwards and reads newspapers upside down. The title recalls the children’s game of trying to pick the fault in an image; this experimental film, shot in black and white, encourages the spectator to do the same. A beautiful musical score by Barry Adamson.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Sonia Whiteman

results.title: What's wrong with our schools?
results.brief_description: Milton Friedman argues that the growing role of government in financing and administering schooling has led to enormous waste of taxpayers money but also to an inferior education system than would have developed had voluntary co-operation played a larger role.
results.description: Milton Friedman argues that the growing role of government in financing and administering schooling has led to enormous waste of taxpayers money but also to an inferior education system than would have developed had voluntary co-operation played a larger role.

results.title: What's up Tiger Lily?
results.creator_credit: American International Pictures (AIP), Castle Hill and Woody Allen
results.brief_description: A self-reflexive spy spoof, “What’s up Tiger Lily?” marked Woody Allen’s feature debut. Here Allen takes an original Japanese film entitled “Kagi no kagi” and replaces the dialogue with dubbed English to create a comic send-up of a James Bond style crime solving flick. Phil Moskowitz, a loveable rogue is on a deadly mission to prevent a winning recipe for egg-salad from falling into the wrong hands. With the help of some beautiful aides, Moskowitz must foil the plans of the evil Shepherd Wong. The film features a bevy of Japanese beauties and falls into predictable notions of gender and genre. Allen followed up this film with other slapstick comedies such as “Bananas” and “Take the money and run” at the start of a prolific and successful career as a writer/director/actor.

results.title: What's up Doc?
results.creator_credit: Saticoy Productions, Warner Bros Pictures and Peter Bogdanovich
results.brief_description: Taking its cues from the classic 1930s screwball comedies of Howard Hawks and Preston Sturges, “What’s up Doc” is most reminiscent (more or less a remake) of “Bringing up Baby” (Hawks, 1938). Barbra Streisand plays the flighty university student Judy Maxwell, who has trouble deciding which course she is in, creating chaos wherever she goes with her free-spirited presence. After spying nerdy musicologist Howard Bannister (Ryan O’Neal), Judy decides they are a perfect match and sets her romantic sights on him. As per the genre, Howard has an equally nebbish fiancee, who is of course but a minor obstacle in the course of true love. The film scores lots of laughs with a series of mixed up suitcases, missing jewels, an extensive chase scene, and romantic interludes. “What’s up Doc?” manages a successful mix of rapid fire dialogue, physical comedy and charming lead performances, which made it one of the big hits of 1972, the second in a row for director Peter Bogdanovich (The Last Picture show, Paper moon, The Cat’s meow). Features several songs by Barbra Streisand.

results.title: What's under the label
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Donald Mulholland and Ronald Weyman
results.brief_description: Precautions taken to safeguard the food and drugs sold in Canada. This film is the story of how Canada’s pure food and drug laws are enforced - the checking of food in retail stores, testing in Government laboratories, and destruction of faulty products. With new foods and drugs coming on the market daily, the film points out that constant vigilance is essential for the protection of the Canadian consumer.
